etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in John Ash (1724–1779), lexicographer and grammarian. From French ablette the bleak from able denoting various cyprinid fishes (1393; from post-classical Latin abula, alteration (with dissimilation of l) of classical Latin albula small fish from albus white + -ula; compare Italian regional (Marche) avola) + -ette

definitions: The bleak, Alburnus alburnus, a cyprinid fish.

notes.text: Formerly apparently in English regional use, but later chiefly in French contexts.
